policy_summary: The original owner must remove the license plates from the vehicle upon transfer of ownership. The original owner can then transfer the registration and license plates to another vehicle they own within 30 days, under certain conditions. If the vehicle is transferred due to death, the registration and any license plates may be retained by the new owner. Commercial vehicles with a weight over 10,000 pounds are allowed to shift registration to other vehicles owned by the owner without a change of the vehicle's ownership.
dmv_excerpt: Upon the transfer of ownership of a motor vehicle, the registration of the motor vehicle expires, and the original owner immediately shall remove the license plates from the motor vehicle. If the original owner of a motor vehicle that has been transferred makes application for the registration of another motor vehicle at any time during the remainder of the registration period for which the transferred motor vehicle was registered, the owner may file an application for transfer of the registration and, where applicable, the license plates.
highlighted_quote: Upon the transfer of ownership of a motor vehicle, the registration of the motor vehicle expires, and the **original owner immediately shall remove the license plates** from the motor vehicle. If the original owner of a motor vehicle that has been transferred makes application for the registration of another motor vehicle at any time during the remainder of the registration period for which the transferred motor vehicle was registered, the owner may **file an application for transfer of the registration and, where applicable, the license plates**.
final_summary: The original owner must remove the license plates from the vehicle upon transfer of ownership. The original owner can then transfer the registration and license plates to another vehicle they own within 30 days, under certain conditions. If the vehicle is transferred due to death, the registration and any license plates may be retained by the new owner. Commercial vehicles with a weight over 10,000 pounds are allowed to shift registration to other vehicles owned by the owner without a change of the vehicle's ownership.
final_quote: Upon the transfer of ownership of a motor vehicle, the registration of the motor vehicle expires, and the original owner immediately shall remove the license plates from the motor vehicle. If the original owner of a motor vehicle that has been transferred makes application for the registration of another motor vehicle at any time during the remainder of the registration period for which the transferred motor vehicle was registered, the owner may file an application for transfer of the registration and, where applicable, the license plates.

policy_summary: The license plate should be transferred to the new vehicle purchased by the same seller.
dmv_excerpt: If you own a vehicle or trailer and purchase a new vehicle or trailer from an individual, you may transfer your registration to the newly acquired vehicle. Massachusetts allows a grace period of 7 calendar days from the date you dispose of your previous vehicle to register your newly acquired vehicle.
highlighted_quote: If you own a vehicle or trailer and purchase a new vehicle or trailer from an individual, you may **transfer your registration** to the newly acquired vehicle.
final_summary: The license plate should be transferred to the new vehicle purchased by the same seller.
final_quote: If you own a vehicle or trailer and purchase a new vehicle or trailer from an individual, you may transfer your registration to the newly acquired vehicle. Massachusetts allows a grace period of 7 calendar days from the date you dispose of your previous vehicle to register your newly acquired vehicle.
evaluation_notes: Policy specific to same owner transfers

policy_summary: In Connecticut, the license plates should be removed by the seller when the vehicle is sold. The seller should subsequently cancel their registration with the DMV.
dmv_excerpt: Remove your plates from the vehicle and cancel your registration with DMV. If canceling online, be sure to print out your receipt.
highlighted_quote: **Remove your plates from the vehicle** and cancel your registration with DMV. If canceling online, be sure to print out your receipt.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: In Connecticut, the license plates should be removed by the seller when the vehicle is sold. The seller should subsequently cancel their registration with the DMV.
final_quote: Remove your plates from the vehicle and cancel your registration with DMV. If canceling online, be sure to print out your receipt.

policy_summary: Policy not found - manual validation needed
plate_retention_policy: Policy not found - manual validation needed

policy_summary: In Michigan, license plates stay with the seller who may transfer the plate to another vehicle they own or purchase. Transfers are only possible when selling the vehicle to an immediate family member. Plates should be immediately removed upon selling the vehicle and should not be allowed to be used by the buyer.
dmv_excerpt: If I sell my car, can I let the buyer use my plate? No - immediately remove your plate upon selling the vehicle. You can transfer the plate to another vehicle you own or purchase. Do not let a buyer 'borrow' your plate, as any violations (including parking tickets) issued to the buyer with your plate on the vehicle will be your responsibility.
highlighted_quote: No - **immediately remove your plate** upon selling the vehicle. You can **transfer the plate to another vehicle you own** or purchase.
final_summary: In Michigan, license plates stay with the seller who may transfer the plate to another vehicle they own or purchase. Transfers are only possible when selling the vehicle to an immediate family member. Plates should be immediately removed upon selling the vehicle and should not be allowed to be used by the buyer.
final_quote: If I sell my car, can I let the buyer use my plate? No - immediately remove your plate upon selling the vehicle. You can transfer the plate to another vehicle you own or purchase. Do not let a buyer 'borrow' your plate, as any violations (including parking tickets) issued to the buyer with your plate on the vehicle will be your responsibility.

policy_summary: The license plate should stay with the seller and can be transferred to a newly acquired vehicle if the old vehicle was traded in at a licensed Dealer and listed as a trade-in on the purchase contract. If the vehicle was sold through a private party sale, the license plate cannot be displayed on the new vehicle until new registration is obtained. Expired license plates can either be returned, discarded, or cut in half to prevent unlawful use.
dmv_excerpt: If you trade in a vehicle to a licensed Dealer, and they list that vehicle as a trade-in on your purchase contract, you can put your plates from your old vehicle onto the new one. If you sell your vehicle in a separate transaction (traded it in on a different car or sold it through a private party sale) you cannot display your old plates on the vehicle until you have obtained a new registration that shows they have been reassigned to your new vehicle.
highlighted_quote: If you trade in a vehicle to a **licensed Dealer**, and they list that vehicle as a **trade-in** on your purchase contract, you can **put your plates from your old vehicle onto the new one**. If you sell your vehicle in a separate transaction (traded it in on a different car or sold it through a private party sale) you **cannot display your old plates on the vehicle** until you have obtained a **new registration** that shows they have been **reassigned to your new vehicle**.
final_summary: The license plate should stay with the seller and can be transferred to a newly acquired vehicle if the old vehicle was traded in at a licensed Dealer and listed as a trade-in on the purchase contract. If the vehicle was sold through a private party sale, the license plate cannot be displayed on the new vehicle until new registration is obtained. Expired license plates can either be returned, discarded, or cut in half to prevent unlawful use.
final_quote: If you trade in a vehicle to a licensed Dealer, and they list that vehicle as a trade-in on your purchase contract, you can put your plates from your old vehicle onto the new one. If you sell your vehicle in a separate transaction (traded it in on a different car or sold it through a private party sale) you cannot display your old plates on the vehicle until you have obtained a new registration that shows they have been reassigned to your new vehicle.

policy_summary: In Nevada, the license plate should be removed by the seller and then transferred or surrendered.
dmv_excerpt: The seller should remove the license plates and transfer or surrender them.
highlighted_quote: The seller should **remove the license plates** and **transfer or surrender** them.
final_summary: In Nevada, the license plate should be removed by the seller and then transferred or surrendered.
final_quote: The seller should remove the license plates and transfer or surrender them.

policy_summary: Policy not found - manual validation needed
plate_retention_policy: Policy not found - manual validation needed

policy_summary: Policy not found - manual validation needed
plate_retention_policy: Policy not found - manual validation needed

policy_summary: In Tennessee, license plates stay with the owner, not the vehicle, and can be transferred to a different vehicle for a fee. Plates should be destroyed when no longer meeting eligibility criteria or are damaged beyond use.
dmv_excerpt: Tennessee license plates follow the owner, not the vehicle, and can be transferred to a different vehicle for a $1 fee. Immediately destroy a plate when: you no longer meet its eligibility criteria and the vehicle registration is not expired; or it is mutilated or effaced and no longer meets requirements of the law.
highlighted_quote: Tennessee license plates **follow the owner**, not the vehicle, and can be transferred to a different vehicle for a $1 fee. Immediately **destroy a plate** when: you no longer meet its eligibility criteria and the vehicle registration is not expired; or it is mutilated or effaced and no longer meets requirements of the law.
final_summary: In Tennessee, license plates stay with the owner, not the vehicle, and can be transferred to a different vehicle for a fee. Plates should be destroyed when no longer meeting eligibility criteria or are damaged beyond use.
final_quote: Tennessee license plates follow the owner, not the vehicle, and can be transferred to a different vehicle for a $1 fee. Immediately destroy a plate when: you no longer meet its eligibility criteria and the vehicle registration is not expired; or it is mutilated or effaced and no longer meets requirements of the law.

policy_summary: The license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
dmv_excerpt: Both vehicles must be titled and registered in the same owner(s) name(s).
highlighted_quote: **Both vehicles must be titled and registered in the same owner(s) name(s)**.
final_summary: The license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
final_quote: Both vehicles must be titled and registered in the same owner(s) name(s).

policy_summary: Policy not found - manual validation needed
plate_retention_policy: Policy not found - manual validation needed

policy_summary: In Alabama, the license plate must be removed by the seller upon the sale of the vehicle. The license plate may possibly be transferred to another vehicle, if acquired by the seller.
dmv_excerpt: License plates are to be removed by the registrant upon the sale or disposal of the vehicle.  If another vehicle is acquired, you may be able to transfer your license plate to this newly acquired vehicle. Please contact your license plate issuing offices for further information.
highlighted_quote: License plates are to be **removed by the registrant** upon the sale or disposal of the vehicle.  If another vehicle is acquired, you may be able to **transfer your license plate** to this newly acquired vehicle.
final_summary: In Alabama, the license plate must be removed by the seller upon the sale of the vehicle. The license plate may possibly be transferred to another vehicle, if acquired by the seller.
final_quote: License plates are to be removed by the registrant upon the sale or disposal of the vehicle.  If another vehicle is acquired, you may be able to transfer your license plate to this newly acquired vehicle. Please contact your license plate issuing offices for further information.

policy_summary: The license plate should stay with the seller in Alaska
dmv_excerpt: If your vehicle has personalized/specialty plates , remove the plates upon sale. The buyer will be issued a new set of plates at no additional charge and can pick up the vehicle after transferring it to their name.
highlighted_quote: If your vehicle has personalized/specialty plates , **remove the plates upon sale**. The buyer will be issued a new set of plates at no additional charge and can pick up the vehicle after transferring it to their name.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: The license plate should stay with the seller in Alaska
final_quote: If your vehicle has personalized/specialty plates , remove the plates upon sale. The buyer will be issued a new set of plates at no additional charge and can pick up the vehicle after transferring it to their name.

policy_summary: In Arizona, when a vehicle is sold or otherwise transferred, license plates should either be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller or destroyed. They do not stay with the sold vehicle.
dmv_excerpt: When a vehicle is sold (or otherwise transferred) you, the seller, are required to remove the license plate from the vehicle and contact MVD to transfer it to another vehicle you own, or destroy it.
highlighted_quote: When a vehicle is sold (or otherwise transferred) you, the seller, are required to **remove the license plate** from the vehicle and contact MVD to **transfer it to another vehicle you own, or destroy it**.
final_summary: In Arizona, when a vehicle is sold or otherwise transferred, license plates should either be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller or destroyed. They do not stay with the sold vehicle.
final_quote: When a vehicle is sold (or otherwise transferred) you, the seller, are required to remove the license plate from the vehicle and contact MVD to transfer it to another vehicle you own, or destroy it.

policy_summary: Policy not found - manual validation needed
dmv_excerpt: Manual validation required

policy_summary: In California, standard license plates remain with the vehicle when ownership is transferred. Personalized, special interest, and disabled person license plates belong to the plate owner and must be removed when the vehicle is sold unless the owner wishes to transfer interest to the new owner.
dmv_excerpt: Most vehicles have sequentially issued “standard” license plates that remain with the vehicle when ownership is transferred. Disabled person, special interest, or personalized license plates belong to the plate owner, not the vehicle. As the seller of a vehicle with disabled person, special interest, or personalized license plates, you must remove the plates. If you wish to release your interest in the special interest or personalized license plates to the new owner, complete a Special Interest License Plate Application (REG 17 (PDF)) form releasing your interest and give the form to the buyer.
highlighted_quote: Most vehicles have sequentially issued “standard” license plates that **remain with the vehicle** when ownership is transferred.
final_summary: In California, standard license plates remain with the vehicle when ownership is transferred. Personalized, special interest, and disabled person license plates belong to the plate owner and must be removed when the vehicle is sold unless the owner wishes to transfer interest to the new owner.
final_quote: Most vehicles have sequentially issued “standard” license plates that remain with the vehicle when ownership is transferred. Disabled person, special interest, or personalized license plates belong to the plate owner, not the vehicle. As the seller of a vehicle with disabled person, special interest, or personalized license plates, you must remove the plates. If you wish to release your interest in the special interest or personalized license plates to the new owner, complete a Special Interest License Plate Application (REG 17 (PDF)) form releasing your interest and give the form to the buyer.

policy_summary: The license plates in Colorado stay with the seller and should be removed from the vehicle when sold.
dmv_excerpt: License Plates. Seller keeps license plates. These should be removed from the vehicle.
highlighted_quote: License Plates. **Seller keeps license plates**. These should be removed from the vehicle.
final_summary: The license plates in Colorado stay with the seller and should be removed from the vehicle when sold.
final_quote: License Plates. Seller keeps license plates. These should be removed from the vehicle.

policy_summary: The license plate must be removed from the vehicle and returned to the DMV when the vehicle is sold. If the seller does not return the license plate, they risk receiving violations as the vehicle may not be properly transferred to the new buyer.
dmv_excerpt: The license plate must be removed from the vehicle and returned to any DMV office.* Please note that if the license plate is not returned or retained with the DMV by the seller, they may run the risk of receiving violations; such as red light, toll or parking violations, which may occur should their vehicle not be properly transferred to the new buyer.
highlighted_quote: The license plate **must be removed from the vehicle and returned to any DMV office**. Please note that if the license plate is not **returned or retained with the DMV by the seller**, they may run the risk of receiving violations; such as red light, toll or parking violations, which may occur should their vehicle not be properly transferred to the new buyer.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: The license plate must be removed from the vehicle and returned to the DMV when the vehicle is sold. If the seller does not return the license plate, they risk receiving violations as the vehicle may not be properly transferred to the new buyer.
final_quote: The license plate must be removed from the vehicle and returned to any DMV office.* Please note that if the license plate is not returned or retained with the DMV by the seller, they may run the risk of receiving violations; such as red light, toll or parking violations, which may occur should their vehicle not be properly transferred to the new buyer.

policy_summary: The license plate must be surrendered to the DMV by the seller if the seller does not plan to transfer the vehicle tags.
dmv_excerpt: If you do not plan to transfer your vehicle tags,surrender the tagsto DC DMV either in-person or by certified mail to ensure that DC DMV receives your surrendered vehicle tags.
highlighted_quote: If you do not plan to transfer your vehicle tags,**surrender the tags**to DC DMV either in-person or by certified mail to ensure that DC DMV receives your surrendered vehicle tags.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: The license plate must be surrendered to the DMV by the seller if the seller does not plan to transfer the vehicle tags.
final_quote: If you do not plan to transfer your vehicle tags,surrender the tagsto DC DMV either in-person or by certified mail to ensure that DC DMV receives your surrendered vehicle tags.

policy_summary: In Florida, when motor vehicles are sold, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle and may then transfer the plate to a new or replacement vehicle. However, the seller must surrender the license plate to the DMV if they are moving to another state or if the seller cancels insurance on the vehicle associated with the plate.
dmv_excerpt: In a sale, license plates stay with seller not the vehicle. When motor vehicles are sold, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle and may then transfer the plate to a new or replacement vehicle. The seller must surrender the tag to a motor vehicle service center if: The seller is moving to another state; or The seller cancels insurance on the vehicle associated with the plate.
highlighted_quote: In a sale, license plates **stay with seller** not the vehicle. When motor vehicles are sold, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle and may then transfer the plate to a new or replacement vehicle. The seller must **surrender the tag** to a motor vehicle service center if: The seller is moving to another state; or The seller cancels insurance on the vehicle associated with the plate.
final_summary: In Florida, when motor vehicles are sold, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle and may then transfer the plate to a new or replacement vehicle. However, the seller must surrender the license plate to the DMV if they are moving to another state or if the seller cancels insurance on the vehicle associated with the plate.
final_quote: In a sale, license plates stay with seller not the vehicle. When motor vehicles are sold, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle and may then transfer the plate to a new or replacement vehicle. The seller must surrender the tag to a motor vehicle service center if: The seller is moving to another state; or The seller cancels insurance on the vehicle associated with the plate.

policy_summary: The license plate stays with the seller when a vehicle is sold in Georgia. The seller can keep the license plates in their personal possession, transfer them to another vehicle they own, or surrender them to the Department of Revenue (DOR) for cancellation.
dmv_excerpt: The previous owner should keep the vehicle’s license plate and any tags. These do not transfer with the vehicle to its new owner. The previous owner can keep the license plates in their personal possession, transfer the license plate to a new vehicle, or surrender the license plate to the DOR for cancellation.
highlighted_quote: The previous owner should **keep the vehicle’s license plate** and any tags. These do not transfer with the vehicle to its new owner. The previous owner can **keep the license plates in their personal possession**, **transfer the license plate to a new vehicle**, or **surrender the license plate to the DOR for cancellation**.
final_summary: The license plate stays with the seller when a vehicle is sold in Georgia. The seller can keep the license plates in their personal possession, transfer them to another vehicle they own, or surrender them to the Department of Revenue (DOR) for cancellation.
final_quote: The previous owner should keep the vehicle’s license plate and any tags. These do not transfer with the vehicle to its new owner. The previous owner can keep the license plates in their personal possession, transfer the license plate to a new vehicle, or surrender the license plate to the DOR for cancellation.

policy_summary: Policy not found - manual validation needed
plate_retention_policy: Policy not found - manual validation needed

policy_summary: The license plate should stay with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
dmv_excerpt: Keep your license plates when selling a vehicle. The license plates you display on your vehicle is yours to keep. When you sell/transfer a vehicle, take the plates off your vehicle. By keeping your plates, you can transfer them to another vehicle and receive credit for any remaining time on your registration.
highlighted_quote: Keep your **license plates when selling a vehicle**. The license plates you display on your vehicle is **yours to keep**. When you sell/transfer a vehicle, **take the plates off your vehicle**. By keeping your plates, you can transfer them to another vehicle and receive credit for any remaining time on your registration.
final_summary: The license plate should stay with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
final_quote: Keep your license plates when selling a vehicle. The license plates you display on your vehicle is yours to keep. When you sell/transfer a vehicle, take the plates off your vehicle. By keeping your plates, you can transfer them to another vehicle and receive credit for any remaining time on your registration.

policy_summary: In Indiana, the license plate should stay with the seller when a vehicle is sold. The seller is recommended to remove it at the time of transaction. Also, the license plates of sold vehicles do not have to be returned to BMV, they can be transferred to a different vehicle owned by that same person.
dmv_excerpt: The seller should remove the license plate from the vehicle at the time of the transaction. The Indiana BMV does not require the license plates of sold vehicles to be returned to the BMV. The license plates of sold vehicles may be transferred to a different vehicle owned by that same person.
highlighted_quote: The **seller should remove the license plate** from the vehicle at the time of the transaction. The Indiana BMV does not require the license plates of sold vehicles to be **returned to the BMV**. The license plates of sold vehicles may be **transferred to a different vehicle owned by that same person**.
final_summary: In Indiana, the license plate should stay with the seller when a vehicle is sold. The seller is recommended to remove it at the time of transaction. Also, the license plates of sold vehicles do not have to be returned to BMV, they can be transferred to a different vehicle owned by that same person.
final_quote: The seller should remove the license plate from the vehicle at the time of the transaction. The Indiana BMV does not require the license plates of sold vehicles to be returned to the BMV. The license plates of sold vehicles may be transferred to a different vehicle owned by that same person.

policy_summary: In Iowa, the license plate stays with the seller when the vehicle is sold. The seller must remove the license plates and keep them. If another vehicle is purchased within 30 days, the plates can be put on that vehicle, provided the fees are paid on the replacement vehicle. If a replacement vehicle is not purchased, the plates must be turned into the county treasurer.
dmv_excerpt: After delivering the vehicle to the dealer, remove the license plates and keep them. If another vehicle is purchased within 30 days, the plates can be put on that vehicle, provided the fees are paid on the replacement vehicle. If a replacement vehicle is not purchased, turn the plates in to the county treasurer.
highlighted_quote: After delivering the vehicle to the dealer, **remove the license plates and keep them**. If another vehicle is purchased within 30 days, the plates can be put on that vehicle, provided the fees are paid on the replacement vehicle. If a replacement vehicle is not purchased, **turn the plates in to the county treasurer**.
final_summary: In Iowa, the license plate stays with the seller when the vehicle is sold. The seller must remove the license plates and keep them. If another vehicle is purchased within 30 days, the plates can be put on that vehicle, provided the fees are paid on the replacement vehicle. If a replacement vehicle is not purchased, the plates must be turned into the county treasurer.
final_quote: After delivering the vehicle to the dealer, remove the license plates and keep them. If another vehicle is purchased within 30 days, the plates can be put on that vehicle, provided the fees are paid on the replacement vehicle. If a replacement vehicle is not purchased, turn the plates in to the county treasurer.

policy_summary: The license plate must be removed by the seller when the vehicle or trailer is transferred to a new owner.
dmv_excerpt: The previous owner must remove their license plate from the vehicle or trailer once the title is assigned and the vehicle or trailer is delivered.
highlighted_quote: The previous owner must **remove their license plate** from the vehicle or trailer once the title is assigned and the vehicle or trailer is delivered.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: The license plate must be removed by the seller when the vehicle or trailer is transferred to a new owner.
final_quote: The previous owner must remove their license plate from the vehicle or trailer once the title is assigned and the vehicle or trailer is delivered.

policy_summary: In Kentucky, the license plate stays with the seller when a vehicle is sold. The seller can apply the plate to any other vehicle they own of the same class. However, if the registration has expired at the time of the vehicle transfer of ownership, the plate must be returned to the County Clerk's office.
dmv_excerpt: beginning in January, Kentuckians will now keep their license plates when transferring vehicle ownership...when a vehicle is transferred with unexpired registration, the seller retains the plate...If the registration has already expired at the time of the vehicle transfer of ownership, the plate must be returned to the county clerk's office
highlighted_quote: beginning in January, Kentuckians will now **keep their license plates** when transferring vehicle ownership...when a vehicle is transferred with unexpired registration, **the seller retains the plate**...If the registration has already expired at the time of the vehicle transfer of ownership, **the plate must be returned** to the county clerk's office
final_summary: In Kentucky, the license plate stays with the seller when a vehicle is sold. The seller can apply the plate to any other vehicle they own of the same class. However, if the registration has expired at the time of the vehicle transfer of ownership, the plate must be returned to the County Clerk's office.
final_quote: beginning in January, Kentuckians will now keep their license plates when transferring vehicle ownership...when a vehicle is transferred with unexpired registration, the seller retains the plate...If the registration has already expired at the time of the vehicle transfer of ownership, the plate must be returned to the county clerk's office

policy_summary: In Louisiana, regular automobile license plates should be destroyed by the seller. However, truck and trailer plates may stay with the vehicle and be transferred to the new owner. Special prestige license plates may be kept by the seller. Alternatively, license plates may be surrendered.
dmv_excerpt: After successfully completing the 'Notice of Vehicle Transfer' on our web site, regular automobile license plates should be destroyed by the seller. Truck and trailer plates may stay with the vehicle and be transferred to the new owner. Special prestige license plates may be kept by the seller.
highlighted_quote: After successfully completing the 'Notice of Vehicle Transfer' on our web site, **regular automobile license plates should be destroyed by the seller**. Truck and trailer plates **may stay with the vehicle and be transferred to the new owner**. Special prestige **license plates may be kept by the seller**.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with the seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: In Louisiana, regular automobile license plates should be destroyed by the seller. However, truck and trailer plates may stay with the vehicle and be transferred to the new owner. Special prestige license plates may be kept by the seller. Alternatively, license plates may be surrendered.
final_quote: After successfully completing the 'Notice of Vehicle Transfer' on our web site, regular automobile license plates should be destroyed by the seller. Truck and trailer plates may stay with the vehicle and be transferred to the new owner. Special prestige license plates may be kept by the seller.

policy_summary: In Maine, when the owner of a vehicle transfers or assigns the title or interest in a vehicle, the registration expires. If the registration is suspended, revoked, canceled or has expired and the owner has no intention to renew or transfer within 6 months, the owner needs to return the registration plates and the registration certificate to the Secretary of State. The registration plates can be reassigned if the owner wishes so.
dmv_excerpt: When the owner of a vehicle transfers or assigns title or interest in a vehicle the registration expires. When a registration certificate is suspended, revoked, canceled or has expired and the owner has no intention to renew or transfer within 6 months, the owner shall remove the registration plates and forward them, along with the registration certificate, to the Secretary of State.
highlighted_quote: When the owner of a vehicle transfers or assigns title or interest in a vehicle the registration **expires**. When a registration certificate is suspended, revoked, canceled or has expired and the owner has no intention to renew or transfer within 6 months, the owner shall **remove the registration plates and forward them**, along with the registration certificate, to the Secretary of State.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: In Maine, when the owner of a vehicle transfers or assigns the title or interest in a vehicle, the registration expires. If the registration is suspended, revoked, canceled or has expired and the owner has no intention to renew or transfer within 6 months, the owner needs to return the registration plates and the registration certificate to the Secretary of State. The registration plates can be reassigned if the owner wishes so.
final_quote: When the owner of a vehicle transfers or assigns title or interest in a vehicle the registration expires. When a registration certificate is suspended, revoked, canceled or has expired and the owner has no intention to renew or transfer within 6 months, the owner shall remove the registration plates and forward them, along with the registration certificate, to the Secretary of State.

policy_summary: In Maryland, the license plates stay with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle under certain conditions. Transferring the plates from the sold vehicle to a newly acquired one is allowed if the ownership of the newly acquired vehicle remains the same as the original.
dmv_excerpt: Under certain conditions, you may be permitted to transfer your license plates from an old vehicle to a newly acquired vehicle. Registration plates acquired by any person, for any vehicle owned by that person, may be transferred to a newly acquired vehicle provided: The ownership of the newly acquired vehicle has not changed from the name in which the plates were originally issued; and The vehicle from which the plates are to be transferred has been sold, traded, junked, or otherwise disposed of.
highlighted_quote: Under certain conditions, you may be permitted to **transfer your license plates** from an old vehicle to a newly acquired vehicle. Registration plates acquired by any person, for any vehicle owned by that person, may be transferred to a newly acquired vehicle provided: The ownership of the newly acquired vehicle has not changed from the name in which the plates were originally issued; and The vehicle from which the plates are to be **transferred has been sold**, traded, junked, or otherwise disposed of.
final_summary: In Maryland, the license plates stay with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle under certain conditions. Transferring the plates from the sold vehicle to a newly acquired one is allowed if the ownership of the newly acquired vehicle remains the same as the original.
final_quote: Under certain conditions, you may be permitted to transfer your license plates from an old vehicle to a newly acquired vehicle. Registration plates acquired by any person, for any vehicle owned by that person, may be transferred to a newly acquired vehicle provided: The ownership of the newly acquired vehicle has not changed from the name in which the plates were originally issued; and The vehicle from which the plates are to be transferred has been sold, traded, junked, or otherwise disposed of.

policy_summary: In Minnesota, license plates belong to and stay with the vehicle. They do not belong to a person.
dmv_excerpt: In Minnesota, license plates belong to and stay with the vehicle. They do not belong to a person.
highlighted_quote: In Minnesota, **license plates belong to and stay with the vehicle**. They do not belong to a person.
final_summary: In Minnesota, license plates belong to and stay with the vehicle. They do not belong to a person.
final_quote: In Minnesota, license plates belong to and stay with the vehicle. They do not belong to a person.

policy_summary: When selling or disposing of a vehicle, the license plate must be removed and turned in to the county Tax Collector’s office. Once the tag is turned in, the record for the vehicle showing the seller's name as the owner will no longer be the current ownership record.
dmv_excerpt: You need to remove the license plate(s) from a vehicle or trailer that you have sold or disposed of when handing over the title to the new owner. You should then take the license plate to the county Tax Collector’s office. Once the tag is turned in, the record for the vehicle showing your name as owner will no longer be the current ownership record.
highlighted_quote: You need to **remove the license plate(s)** from a vehicle or trailer that you have sold or disposed of when handing over the title to the new owner. You should then take the license plate to the county Tax Collector’s office. Once the tag is turned in, the record for the vehicle showing your name as owner will no longer be the current ownership record.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: When selling or disposing of a vehicle, the license plate must be removed and turned in to the county Tax Collector’s office. Once the tag is turned in, the record for the vehicle showing the seller's name as the owner will no longer be the current ownership record.
final_quote: You need to remove the license plate(s) from a vehicle or trailer that you have sold or disposed of when handing over the title to the new owner. You should then take the license plate to the county Tax Collector’s office. Once the tag is turned in, the record for the vehicle showing your name as owner will no longer be the current ownership record.

policy_summary: In Missouri, license plates can be transferred to the new vehicle in limited situations and for specific types of vehicle-to-vehicle registration transfers. However, when there is a complete change of ownership, the seller's license plates cannot be transferred to or used by the purchaser.
dmv_excerpt: Credit of registration is available for many types of vehicle-to-vehicle registration transfers. And, in limited situations, the actual license plates may also be transferred to the new vehicle without having to obtain new license plates. NOTE: When there is a complete change of ownership, the seller's license plates cannot be transferred to (or used by) the purchaser.
highlighted_quote: Credit of registration is available for many types of vehicle-to-vehicle registration transfers. And, in **limited situations, the actual license plates may also be transferred to the new vehicle** without having to obtain new license plates. NOTE: When there is a **complete change of ownership**, the seller's license plates **cannot be transferred to (or used by) the purchaser**.
final_summary: In Missouri, license plates can be transferred to the new vehicle in limited situations and for specific types of vehicle-to-vehicle registration transfers. However, when there is a complete change of ownership, the seller's license plates cannot be transferred to or used by the purchaser.
final_quote: Credit of registration is available for many types of vehicle-to-vehicle registration transfers. And, in limited situations, the actual license plates may also be transferred to the new vehicle without having to obtain new license plates. NOTE: When there is a complete change of ownership, the seller's license plates cannot be transferred to (or used by) the purchaser.

policy_summary: In Montana, the license plate remains with the seller after the sale of the vehicle. The seller can request to transfer the plates to another vehicle they own.
dmv_excerpt: The plates belong to you, not the vehicle. Don’t let the buyer drive the vehicle home with the promise that they will return the plates. If you do not remove the plates, you may be liable for any parking or traffic violations that happen after the sale. You can ask to transfer the plates to another vehicle you own.
highlighted_quote: The **plates belong to you**, not the vehicle. Don’t let the buyer drive the vehicle home with the promise that they will return the plates. If you do not remove the plates, you may be liable for any parking or traffic violations that happen after the sale. You can ask to **transfer the plates to another vehicle you own**.
final_summary: In Montana, the license plate remains with the seller after the sale of the vehicle. The seller can request to transfer the plates to another vehicle they own.
final_quote: The plates belong to you, not the vehicle. Don’t let the buyer drive the vehicle home with the promise that they will return the plates. If you do not remove the plates, you may be liable for any parking or traffic violations that happen after the sale. You can ask to transfer the plates to another vehicle you own.

policy_summary: The license plate should be surrendered to the DMV by the seller after a vehicle is sold unless the plate is being transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
dmv_excerpt: The Seller must: Remove the plates and surrender them to a motor vehicle agency, unless the plates are being transferred to another vehicle (plates can be transferred to another vehicle, but not to another owner).
highlighted_quote: The Seller must: **Remove the plates** and **surrender** them to a motor vehicle agency, unless the plates are being **transferred to another vehicle** (plates can be transferred to another vehicle, but not to another owner).
final_summary: The license plate should be surrendered to the DMV by the seller after a vehicle is sold unless the plate is being transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
final_quote: The Seller must: Remove the plates and surrender them to a motor vehicle agency, unless the plates are being transferred to another vehicle (plates can be transferred to another vehicle, but not to another owner).

policy_summary: In New Mexico, the license plate stays with the seller. After a vehicle is sold, traded-in, or given as a gift, the previous owner is responsible for removing the license plate and either surrendering it to the MVD to be destroyed or applying to have it assigned to another vehicle of the same class within 30 days.
dmv_excerpt: New Mexico is a “Vehicle Plate to Owner” state. If the vehicle is sold, traded-in or given as a gift, the vehicle owner is responsible for removing the license plate from the vehicle. Within 30 days of the transaction, the vehicle owner shall take the plate to MVD to have it destroyed, or apply to have the plate assigned to another vehicle of the same class.
highlighted_quote: New Mexico is a **“Vehicle Plate to Owner” state**. If the vehicle is sold, traded-in or given as a gift, the vehicle owner is responsible for removing the license plate from the vehicle. Within 30 days of the transaction, the vehicle owner shall take the plate to MVD to have it destroyed, or apply to have the plate assigned to another vehicle of the same class.
final_summary: In New Mexico, the license plate stays with the seller. After a vehicle is sold, traded-in, or given as a gift, the previous owner is responsible for removing the license plate and either surrendering it to the MVD to be destroyed or applying to have it assigned to another vehicle of the same class within 30 days.
final_quote: New Mexico is a “Vehicle Plate to Owner” state. If the vehicle is sold, traded-in or given as a gift, the vehicle owner is responsible for removing the license plate from the vehicle. Within 30 days of the transaction, the vehicle owner shall take the plate to MVD to have it destroyed, or apply to have the plate assigned to another vehicle of the same class.

policy_summary: In New York, when selling or trading a vehicle, the license plates must be removed and surrendered to the DMV, unless they are being transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
dmv_excerpt: Before you trade in or sell your old vehicle, be sure to remove the license plates and the windshield registration sticker, which shows your plate number. This will help prevent you from being charged with parking tickets that do not belong to you. Turn in the plates to a motor vehicle office unless you are transferring them to a replacement vehicle.
highlighted_quote: Before you trade in or sell your old vehicle, be sure to **remove the license plates** and the windshield registration sticker, which shows your plate number. This will help prevent you from being charged with parking tickets that do not belong to you. **Turn in the plates** to a motor vehicle office unless you are **transferring them to a replacement vehicle**.
final_summary: In New York, when selling or trading a vehicle, the license plates must be removed and surrendered to the DMV, unless they are being transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
final_quote: Before you trade in or sell your old vehicle, be sure to remove the license plates and the windshield registration sticker, which shows your plate number. This will help prevent you from being charged with parking tickets that do not belong to you. Turn in the plates to a motor vehicle office unless you are transferring them to a replacement vehicle.

policy_summary: The license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by them.
dmv_excerpt: To transfer a license plate from one vehicle to another, the individual transferring the plate must meet the following requirements: Maintain on both vehicles liability insurance from a provider licensed to do business in North Carolina. The vehicle to which the license plate is being transferred must have a current inspection. The license plate being transferred must be valid. The name on the applicant's license and the vehicle title must match. Prove the vehicle is covered under liability insurance from a North Carolina-licensed provider.
highlighted_quote: To **transfer a license plate from one vehicle to another**, the individual transferring the plate needs to meet specific requirements.
final_summary: The license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by them.
final_quote: To transfer a license plate from one vehicle to another, the individual transferring the plate must meet the following requirements: Maintain on both vehicles liability insurance from a provider licensed to do business in North Carolina. The vehicle to which the license plate is being transferred must have a current inspection. The license plate being transferred must be valid. The name on the applicant's license and the vehicle title must match. Prove the vehicle is covered under liability insurance from a North Carolina-licensed provider.

policy_summary: In North Dakota, the license plate should be retained by the seller when a vehicle is sold or transferred. A credit towards the registration fee due on the replacement vehicle is allowed for the owner of a vehicle, who has removed their license plate(s) from a vehicle at the time it was sold.
dmv_excerpt: When the owner of a vehicle sells, trades, or otherwise transfers the ownership of the vehicle, the license plate(s) must be removed by the seller and the vehicle will be considered unlicensed. The owner of a vehicle, who has removed their license plate(s) from a vehicle at the time it was sold, is allowed a credit towards the registration fee due on the replacement vehicle.
highlighted_quote: When the owner of a vehicle sells, trades, or otherwise transfers the ownership of the vehicle, the **license plate(s) must be removed by the seller** and the vehicle will be considered unlicensed. The owner of a vehicle, who has **removed their license plate(s)** from a vehicle at the time it was sold, is allowed a credit towards the registration fee due on the replacement vehicle.
final_summary: In North Dakota, the license plate should be retained by the seller when a vehicle is sold or transferred. A credit towards the registration fee due on the replacement vehicle is allowed for the owner of a vehicle, who has removed their license plate(s) from a vehicle at the time it was sold.
final_quote: When the owner of a vehicle sells, trades, or otherwise transfers the ownership of the vehicle, the license plate(s) must be removed by the seller and the vehicle will be considered unlicensed. The owner of a vehicle, who has removed their license plate(s) from a vehicle at the time it was sold, is allowed a credit towards the registration fee due on the replacement vehicle.

policy_summary: In Oklahoma, the license plate is assigned to the individual not the vehicle. If the vehicle is sold, the owner must keep the license plate.
dmv_excerpt: Do I keep my license plate when I move or sell my car? Yes. In Oklahoma, your License Plate is assigned to you, the person, not your vehicle. If you sell your vehicle, it is important that you keep your License Plate.
highlighted_quote: Do I keep my license plate when I move or sell my car? Yes. In Oklahoma, your License Plate is assigned to **you, the person, not your vehicle**. If you sell your vehicle, it is important that **you keep your License Plate**.
final_summary: In Oklahoma, the license plate is assigned to the individual not the vehicle. If the vehicle is sold, the owner must keep the license plate.
final_quote: Do I keep my license plate when I move or sell my car? Yes. In Oklahoma, your License Plate is assigned to you, the person, not your vehicle. If you sell your vehicle, it is important that you keep your License Plate.

policy_summary: The license plate should be removed by the seller when selling the vehicle
dmv_excerpt: One way to ensure you don’t get tickets or towing charges after selling your car is to remove the plates when you sell it. Then the buyer can drive it away with a 21-day trip permit from DMV.
highlighted_quote: One way to ensure you don’t get tickets or towing charges after selling your car is to **remove the plates** when you sell it. Then the buyer can drive it away with a 21-day trip permit from DMV.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: License plate retained by seller during vehicle sale
final_quote: One way to ensure you don’t get tickets or towing charges after selling your car is to remove the plates when you sell it. Then the buyer can drive it away with a 21-day trip permit from DMV.

policy_summary: In Pennsylvania, the license plate does not stay with the vehicle when it is sold - instead it must be removed by the seller. The license plate can either be surrendered back to the DMV, or the seller may transfer it to another vehicle that they own.
dmv_excerpt: After the title is transferred, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle. The license plate should be returned to PennDOT at Bureau of Motor Vehicles, Return Tag Unit, P.O. Box 68597, Harrisburg, PA 17106-8597, unless the seller is planning to transfer the plate to another vehicle.
highlighted_quote: After the title is transferred, the seller must **remove the license plate from the vehicle**. The license plate should be **returned to PennDOT** at Bureau of Motor Vehicles, Return Tag Unit, P.O. Box 68597, Harrisburg, PA 17106-8597, **unless the seller is planning to transfer the plate to another vehicle**.
final_summary: In Pennsylvania, the license plate does not stay with the vehicle when it is sold - instead it must be removed by the seller. The license plate can either be surrendered back to the DMV, or the seller may transfer it to another vehicle that they own.
final_quote: After the title is transferred, the seller must remove the license plate from the vehicle. The license plate should be returned to PennDOT at Bureau of Motor Vehicles, Return Tag Unit, P.O. Box 68597, Harrisburg, PA 17106-8597, unless the seller is planning to transfer the plate to another vehicle.

policy_summary: The license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to a new vehicle with the same owner.
dmv_excerpt: A transfer of registration takes place when you move an existing Rhode Island registration to a new vehicle with the same owner.
highlighted_quote: A transfer of registration takes place when you **move an existing Rhode Island registration to a new vehicle with the same owner**.
final_summary: The license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to a new vehicle with the same owner.
final_quote: A transfer of registration takes place when you move an existing Rhode Island registration to a new vehicle with the same owner.

policy_summary: In South Dakota, the license plate stays with the seller when a vehicle is sold. The owner should transfer the license plates from the old vehicle to the new one.
dmv_excerpt: South Dakota is a plate with owner state. This means that the license plates are retained by the owner. If you purchase a new vehicle, you will transfer the license plates from your old vehicle to your newly acquired vehicle. You can do this at your local county treasurer's office.
highlighted_quote: South Dakota is a **plate with owner** state. This means that the **license plates are retained by the owner**.
final_summary: In South Dakota, the license plate stays with the seller when a vehicle is sold. The owner should transfer the license plates from the old vehicle to the new one.
final_quote: South Dakota is a plate with owner state. This means that the license plates are retained by the owner. If you purchase a new vehicle, you will transfer the license plates from your old vehicle to your newly acquired vehicle. You can do this at your local county treasurer's office.

policy_summary: In Texas, when an owner decides to sell or dispose of their vehicle, they do not need to keep their license plates. However, the license plates should not be reused fraudulently and therefore should be defaced by the seller using permanent black ink or a similar method.
dmv_excerpt: If you decide not to keep your license plates when you sell or dispose of your vehicle, the plates should be disposed of by defacing the front of the plate with permanent black ink, or similar method, in order to prevent their fraudulent use.
highlighted_quote: If you decide **not to keep your license plates** when you sell or dispose of your vehicle, the plates should be disposed of by **defacing the front of the plate** with permanent black ink, or similar method, in order to prevent their fraudulent use.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: In Texas, when an owner decides to sell or dispose of their vehicle, they do not need to keep their license plates. However, the license plates should not be reused fraudulently and therefore should be defaced by the seller using permanent black ink or a similar method.
final_quote: If you decide not to keep your license plates when you sell or dispose of your vehicle, the plates should be disposed of by defacing the front of the plate with permanent black ink, or similar method, in order to prevent their fraudulent use.

policy_summary: In Utah, the license plate should stay with the seller when a vehicle is sold.
dmv_excerpt: When you sell your vehicle: Remove your license plate from the vehicle. If you do not, you may be liable for any parking or traffic violations occurring while your plate remains on the car.
highlighted_quote: When you sell your vehicle: **Remove your license plate from the vehicle**. If you do not, you may be liable for any parking or traffic violations occurring while your plate remains on the car.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: In Utah, the license plate should stay with the seller when a vehicle is sold.
final_quote: When you sell your vehicle: Remove your license plate from the vehicle. If you do not, you may be liable for any parking or traffic violations occurring while your plate remains on the car.

policy_summary: In Vermont, license plates should not be left on the vehicle when sold. Owners are not required to return the plates to the DMV but can do so if they prefer.
dmv_excerpt: You are not required to return plates to DMV. If you want to return plates, please mail them to us. If you are selling your car, do NOT leave your plates on the car.
highlighted_quote: If you are selling your car, do **NOT leave your plates** on the car.
final_summary: In Vermont, license plates should not be left on the vehicle when sold. Owners are not required to return the plates to the DMV but can do so if they prefer.
final_quote: You are not required to return plates to DMV. If you want to return plates, please mail them to us. If you are selling your car, do NOT leave your plates on the car.

policy_summary: In Virginia, upon selling, trading, or no longer operating a vehicle, the law requires one to immediately surrender their license plates and/or vehicle registration to the DMV.
dmv_excerpt: If so, Virginia law requires you to immediately surrender your license plates and/or vehicle registration to DMV.
highlighted_quote: If so, Virginia law requires you to immediately **surrender your license plates** and/or vehicle registration to DMV.
plate_retention_policy: Plate stays with seller (must surrender to DMV or destroy)
final_summary: In Virginia, upon selling, trading, or no longer operating a vehicle, the law requires one to immediately surrender their license plates and/or vehicle registration to the DMV.
final_quote: If so, Virginia law requires you to immediately surrender your license plates and/or vehicle registration to DMV.

policy_summary: In Washington, the license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
dmv_excerpt: You can transfer your vehicle license plates to another vehicle if the new vehicle is: Titled and registered in your name. and Registered in Washington State.
highlighted_quote: You can **transfer your vehicle license plates** to another vehicle if the new vehicle is: Titled and registered in your name. and Registered in Washington State.
final_summary: In Washington, the license plate stays with the seller and can be transferred to another vehicle owned by the seller.
final_quote: You can transfer your vehicle license plates to another vehicle if the new vehicle is: Titled and registered in your name. and Registered in Washington State.

policy_summary: In Wyoming, license plates stay with the seller. They may transfer the plates to their new vehicle or trailer.
dmv_excerpt: Yes, in Wyoming all license plates are sold to you, not to your vehicle. If you plan to replace your vehicle or trailer, you can transfer the plates and any remaining credit to the new vehicle or trailer.
highlighted_quote: Yes, in Wyoming all license plates are **sold to you**, not to your vehicle. **If you plan to replace your vehicle** or trailer, you can **transfer the plates** and any remaining credit to the new vehicle or trailer.
final_summary: In Wyoming, license plates stay with the seller. They may transfer the plates to their new vehicle or trailer.
final_quote: Yes, in Wyoming all license plates are sold to you, not to your vehicle. If you plan to replace your vehicle or trailer, you can transfer the plates and any remaining credit to the new vehicle or trailer.
